ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Very helpful continuation of GMAN 110, where noticeable progress can be seen by the end of the semester. Speaking freely and remains challenging, but not impossible, while reading and writing skills advance meaningfully versus the end of 110.
Increased German proficiency in speaking, reading, writing, and listening

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: A very good mix of different learning materials (textbook, films, cultural works) that become increasingly accessible as student advances throughout the semester. Workload is significant but not unmanageable with regular dedication, and course structure offers lots of space for feedback.  

Weaknesses: N/A (textbook material uninteresting at times, but that is hardly the course's fault).

Strengths: La!! She is an amazing professor! La explains things very clearly, creates an open class environment where people feel comfortable learning by making mistakes, and it is clear that she really cares about her students. 

Weaknesses: this is not specific to the instructor, but the workload for this course is very high. I know that it is a 1.5 credit course, but it often feels more like a 2 credit course given the amount of assignments. I have taken two other introductory language classes at Yale, and this course had far more work compared to the other two.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: ABSOLUTELY! As someone who came to Yale with zero experience with German, this course built upon the basics of L1, improving my reading, writing, speaking, and listening to a huge degree. All the professors are very kind and encouraging, and the classroom was always a welcoming space.

I would recommend the course unquestionably to someone with an interest in pursuing German language studies. Like many other language courses the workload is not trivial, but the reward for a considered study is genuinely uplifting.
Yes; for anyone who is serious about wanting to learn German and to do so in a rigorous environment, I would recommend that they take this class.
